awd_titl_txt: A Framework for Exploring Data in Heterogeneous Sensor Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Heterogeneous sensing systems consisting of sensors with different types of sensing and communication capabilities offer flexibility and facilitate the acquisition of different views of a monitored field by acquiring different types of measurements. The main challenge is that the often large amount of acquired raw sensed data does not provide any clue of what lies beneath the sensed field. The acquired sensor data contain information about different and unknown in number phenomena of interest. The vision of this project is the development and analysis of an algorithmic framework that has the ability to learn the unknown structure of a monitored field and enable the mining and exploration of information in heterogeneous sensor data. The techniques developed in this project will enable learning of the sensed field while effectively reducing the usually large amount of sensor data that need to be processed by removing irrelevant and non-informative sensor measurements. This research project will introduce benefits in a wide span of areas including analysis and mining of ecological and climatic data.  The proposed techniques will be capable of analyzing heterogeneous sensor data sets with different information content and adhering to different statistical models. It will pave the way for efficient learning schemes that extract the informative portion of the sensed data, and remove irrelevant or noisy sensor measurements that can hurt any subsequent data processing/inference task.

The project focuses on the development of general algorithms that have learning capabilities and can identify different informative portions, in a data vector sequence, which may adhere to different data models. The task of clustering data into groups that contain information about different sources is translated into a sparsity-aware canonical correlation analysis formulation. Building on this link, a generalized toolbox is proposed to address settings where the number of information sources and their statistical behavior is unknown. The proposed framework has the potential to uncover multiple information data clusters that may exhibit different statistical behavior, and separate them before applying standard statistical inference tasks. Different from the notion of outliers which are present in a small number of data, the project involves the design of a novel framework that allows the extraction and elimination of corrupted data affecting an arbitrary in size data portion. The idea is to exploit the low-dimensionality that informative data usually have, and identify corrupted data by controlling the rank of the corresponding covariance matrix to be in agreement with the low dimension of the informative data. Distributed optimization tools are also explored to deal with high-dimensional and spatially scattered data.

por.por_cntn:
The algorithmic framework developed in this project will lead to wireless sensor networks with increased life expectancy that will have a beneficial impact on the quality of life and society. Many of the deployment sites are difficult to be accessed by humans, while different types of measurements need to be acquired and processed. This calls for the utilization of heterogeneous networks of sensors along with smart distributed processing techniques that can extract the informative components of the sensed data. Specifically, the use of `smart' networks of sensors will help reduce human intervention in tasks such as health inspection of large structures, surveillance and environmental monitoring that oftentimes can be costly and dangerous. Other aspects of our daily life will also be improved since sensor networks find wider applicability in traffic monitoring, energy efficient buildings, precision agriculture as well as the collection of ecological, climatic and biomedical data.


 The developed algorithmic framework will introduce benefits in a wide span of fields including analysis of ecological, climatic, remote sensing and biomedical data, as well as in data mining and machine learning. The research involved introduces novel techniques that have the ability to learn, extract and match informative portions from different types of data. The proposed research is pertinent and useful, especially in an era characterized by a data deluge from different types of sensing devices and an ever increasing need to interpret and understand these data. The proposed algorithms have the potential to process and extract useful information from large, distributed and heterogeneous data sets. 


In detail, the project involved the development of an algorithmic framework that has the ability to identify, cluster and match different types of sensor data based on their information content. The techniques developed here enable learning of any sensed field, while effectively reducing the usually large amount of sensor data that need to be processed by removing irrelevant and non-informative sensor measurements.  The project focuses on the development of general algorithms that have learning capabilities and can identify different informative portions, in sensor data, which may adhere to different data models. The task of clustering data into groups that contain information about different sources is translated into a sparsity-aware canonical correlation analysis formulation. Building on this link, a generalized toolbox is proposed to address settings where the number of information sources and their statistical behavior is not available. The novel framework has the potential to uncover multiple information data clusters that may exhibit different statistical behavior, and separate them before applying standard statistical inference tasks. Different from the notion of outliers which are present in a small number of data, the proposed methods involve the design of a novel framework that allows the extraction and elimination of corrupted data affecting an arbitrary in size data portion. The idea is to exploit the low-dimensionality that informative data usually have, and identify corrupted data by controlling the rank of the corresponding covariance matrix to be in agreement with the low dimension of the informative data. Distributed optimization tools are also explored to deal with high-dimensional and spatially scattered data. The  novel framework advanced knowledge in nonlinear machine learning, processing and classification of hyperspectral data, as well as processing and unsupervised clustering of heterogeneous sensor data. 


The project financially supported and helped graduate (Fall 2019) one PhD student. The project resulted several  conference and journal publications (13 publications in total). Further, the PI and his research group were able to attend several top notch international conferences in the topic of signal processing, machine learning and remote sensing. The research outcomes were presented via conference lectures and poster presentations. Graduate students performed cutting edge research in signal processing techniques, optimization and machine learning. The research outcomes led to improved algorithms for information extraction, learning  and  processing of heterogeneous data acquired by different types of sensing devices.
